Journal Story:
In 10 days Kevin and I depart for Harper’s Ferry, WV, where we will attend the Flip Flop Festival and then head north on the Appalachian Trail. Having looked at lots of journal entries, I can’t help but wonder: are we starting way too late? My husband assures me the ATC schedules the FFF, which is a kick-off event, in late April for a good reason. The goal is to avoid the mud season and the black flies in New England, while still capitalizing on the favorable weather in the northern states. If all goes as planned, we’ll reach Katahdin by early August. 
Meanwhile, we have been carefully training and planning. In my next post I’ll share some images of our gear and some thoughts on food. 
By the way, no trail names yet, so I’ll leave that part blank for now.
Mary

I have loaded lots of information about our gear, including weights, on the gear section of this site. Here you can see what some of my gear looks like when it is laid out. The pile on the left is my sleeping bag, liner, stuff sack, and pillow. Not shown is my air mattress. The pile on the right is my clothing and stuff sack, including the clothes I will be wearing.

Here is a picture of Kevin’s clothing, our tent, and assorted gear. His sleeping bag (actually a quilt), liner, and pillow are not pictured, but they almost the same as mine. Yes, he does have a lot fewer clothes than I do, but at least my clothing doesn’t weigh as much!
Four days’ food for 2 people.

Arrived via Amtrak, a slow but pleasant roll, in Harpers Ferry WV yesterday before noon. Neither of us slept much the night before nor on the train. 
Checked into the hotel and then attended  a Q&A session with past flip flop hikers. One of them managed to bring her knitting with her! Maybe she knitted replacement socks. 
Then we rested at the hotel and returned for the dinner event, where we met a wide range of fellow flip floppers, Including a 50ish couple of recently retired civil engineers from Florida, who plan to live on their sailboat after the hike. We had a lot in common! It is definitely an older crowd, Although not entirely, with many people who have just retired. 
Check out is at 11 today, after which we will do a short day to the Ed Garvey shelter.  Our plan is to take it easy for the first couple of weeks. This was some thing yesterday’s panel greatly encouraged to better avoid overuse injuries.
Temperatures were cool. Ariived at Dalgren Backpack Campground around 4:30. Got a shower and made dinner and went to bed relatively early.

Destination: South Arm Road - Human Nature Hostel

Start location: South Arm Road - Human Nature Hostel

Journal Story: It’s hot and sunny, but low humidity. I’m finding that I will need to rebuild my trail legs. Only one other person staying at the shelter.
Nearly all the springs and streams are dry.  Stopped at Bears Den Hostel for water and a break.
had to hike an extra 4.5 miles because the shelter I planned to stay at didn’t have any water
very happy to be clean and dry in an air conditioned room
Got caught in a thunderstorm and had to stop early to take shelter. Ran into Two Shoes, a fellow flip flopped we met in Massachusetts. The storm made the night much cooler so I slept well.
Stopped at Elkwallow Wayside in the morning. Thunderstorm passed nearby but never rained. Cool this morning but hot again in the afternoon.
Lots of beautiful views of the Shenandoah Valley today and no storms. Had lunch at Skylands and dinner at Big Meadows.
I finally did a “12 by 12” (12 miles before noon)
